headline: State officials pushing Trump alternate elector scheme come into focus
sentences:
Committee Chairman Bennie Thompson wrote Tuesday that investigators had obtained correspondence and other “credible evidence” showing Trump campaign aides Brown and Roman “encouraged state legislators to alter the outcome of the 2020 election.”
The committee contends they helped appoint the so-called alternate slates for Trump in key battleground states by “directing Trump campaign staffers” to participate in the scheme.

Cox hosted a Zoom and Facebook Live event on Dec. 2, 2020, where Giuliani was featured and told guests they had to “stand up for a free and fair election.”
In a statement Wednesday, Cox lashed out at the committee, saying that the probe’s senior investigative counsel called her in October and that she met with them without an attorney.

Ward, currently suing the committee to stop them from reviewing her phone metadata, has valuable information as chair of the Arizona Republican Party, investigators said Tuesday,
Ward spoke to Trump multiple times about election certification and played a hugely public role in disseminating Trump’s election fraud falsehoods.

The Jan. 6 committee is pulling more “alternate electors” for former President Donald Trump into focus, this time issuing six subpoenas to a group that includes Trump campaign officials as well as state lawmakers—some of whom are currently running for new powerful statewide offices.

The subpoenas went to Arizona Republican Party Chairwoman Kelli Ward, a longtime Trump supporter, as well as Pennsylvania state Sen. Doug Mastriano, now running for governor there, and Arizona State House Rep. Mark Finchem, now running to be the next secretary of state in Arizona.

The probe reviewing the insurrection at the U.S. Capitol has demanded records and deposition by the first week of March in subpoenas going to state Republican legislators and Trump campaign aides who were involved in alleged efforts to send the bogus certificates to Washington.

Pro-Trump electors were not officially recognized by their respective states, but this did not deter them from affixing their signatures to the certificates anyway and remitting them to the National Archives just like the sanctioned electors for 2020 did that December.

Rudy calls the January 6th committee illegal and says they can’t subpoena anybody pic.twitter.com/Xspn4uUMd5
— Acyn (@Acyn) February 16, 2022
In the meantime, the committee continues zeroing in on the bunk electors, and Tuesday’s tranche expanded those efforts.

In a subpoena to Mastriano, investigators asked him to produce information about his conversations with Trump around “post election activities” and for him to testify about a plan to arrange an alternate in Pennsylvania.

(1)
— Senator Doug Mastriano (@SenMastriano) November 28, 2020
Mastriano was at the Capitol on Jan. 6 and has said publicly that he witnessed “agitators … start pushing the police up the steps” of the complex.

pic.twitter.com/qE9VmCYxqI
— Laura Cox (@LauraCoxMI) February 16, 2022
Cox bristled at the subpoena, saying her concerns over voter irregularities stemmed from her own experience as chair of the Michigan GOP.

The committee also wants to know more about how Mastriano arrived at his conclusions, like this one from November 2020:
x
There is mounting evidence that the PA presidential election was compromised.
Mastriano, who is now running to be governor, should explain to the probe why he believed the assertions of voter fraud, Thompson wrote, or why he supported theories about other irregularities.
Exploring the gambit behind the bogus elector submissions in places like Arizona and Pennsylvania has led investigators to some of the former president’s most ardent supporters in high places.
If this is the case, under Article II, Section 1.2 of the US Constitution, the state legislature has the sole authority to direct the manner of selecting delegates to the Electoral College.
Finchem, investigators say, meant to ask Pence to delay the certification, making him yet another person who called on Trump’s second in command to consider subverting the election results.
Former Michigan Republican Party Chair Laura Cox was subpoenaed too along with Michael Roman, Trump’s director of election operations in 2020, and his deputy, Gary Michael Brown.
The group met to discuss unproven allegations of voter fraud and Finchem, in particular, was heard saying during a break in the meeting that the voter systems had been hacked.
Finchem, however, said he was there to give an “evidence book and letter” to then-Vice President Mike Pence that he believed would confirm evidence of fraud in Arizona.
I just talked to President Trump and he would like me to talk to you and also see if he needs to give you a call to discuss what's happening on the ground in Maricopa.
He was also seen in photos on Jan. 6 posing with former Pennsylvania state Rep. Rick Saccone, who took to social media to celebrate the storming of the Capitol.
Former President Donald Trump is greeted by Arizona Republican Party Chairwoman Kelli Ward before his remarks on immigration and border security in August 2020.
Investigators are interested to speak with Finchem about his role in coordinating a Phoenix-based event with members of Trump’s legal team on Nov. 30, 2020.
The meeting, Cox said, was not recorded because the senior counsel and those accompanying him were taking notes and when she asked to record, they refused.
That excludes an altogether separate raft of subpoenas that were issued to telecommunications companies and banks for metadata and financial records.
Just one day after the election, the committee noted in its subpoena, Ward sent text messages to then-Maricopa County Board Chairman Clint Hickman.
The Arizona official said he was aware when Trump called that the president had made other pressure calls to state election officials in Georgia.
PBS reported last January that the state senator’s campaign paid $3,354 to Wolf Bus Lines over three installments six days before the attack.
Mastriano has denied having any illegal involvement in Jan. 6, saying last May that he followed the directions of all police he encountered.
He was subpoenaed by the Jan. 6 committee as well but as of Wednesday, he’s openly dismissed the probe as illegitimate and overblown.
Advertising dollars have been gobbled up by Big Tech and cash-strapped outlets are being bought and sold to the highest bidder.
“I did not need President Trump or the Trump campaign to push me to question ballot irregularities in Michigan … my guy lost.
We are primarily accountable to readers like you because donations from readers like you are our biggest source of income.
“I know you don’t want to be remembered as the guy who led the charge to certify a fraudulent election,” she wrote.
Campaign finance records have also shown that Mastriano’s campaign spent thousands to send buses to D.C. on Jan. 6.
More than 550 interviews have been conducted by investigators and more than 80 subpoenas have been issued openly.
Ward also sent several texts to Hickman a few days after Trump lost, The Arizona Republic first reported.
“Even disingenuous internet sleuths know that police lines did shift throughout the course of the day.
Lastly, the committee seeks information from former Michigan Republican Party Chairwoman Laura Cox.
Hickman told reporters Trump called him twice in four days after he lost to Biden.
One message on Nov. 17 from Ward reportedly read: “Here is Sidney Powell’s number.
That's not just journalists, but fact-checkers, editors, and administrative staff.
But that does not make raising questions about irregularities a crime,” she said.
A Jan. 6 committee spokesperson declined to comment on Cox’s statement Wednesday.

Much of this scheme was reportedly spearheaded by Trump attorney Rudy Giuliani.
We don't have corporate backers that are only in it for the bottom line.
A voicemail Ward left was more explicit about her contact with Trump.
Ward did not immediately return a request for comment on Wednesday.
